See Acid Sea
Ocean acidification is fundamentally changing the chemistry of the world's oceans and threatening our marine resources. This website takes you through and explores the phenomenon of ocean acidification and the data associated with it.
What is Ocean Acidification?
Ocean acidification is the process where increased levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere lead to a decrease in the ocean's pH , making it more acidic, and this can have harmful effects on marine life, particularly organisms that rely on calcium carbonate for their shells and skeletons.
What is pH?
pH actually relates to the concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in a solution. Imagine it as a ruler numbered from 0 to 14.
The more hydrogen ions there are, the more acidity there is and the lower the pH value.
Ocean acidity has declined by 0.1 in more than 200 years since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution and is projected to decline to 7.9 per cent by 2100.
Drag the slider to see the relationship between pH and hydrogen ions.

Why it becomes a problem?
Ocean acidification creates conditions that erode the minerals used by oysters, clams, lobsters, shrimp, coral reefs, and other marine organisms to build their shells and skeletons.
Ocean acidification leads to changes in marine life, affecting the development of the fishing and tourism industries, and can even jeopardize human health.

CORAL

The impact will be especially strong in the Indo-Pacific region, with up to 20% reductions in the densities of coral skeletons by 2100 in parts of the Coral Triangle—the area

ALGAE

In the laboratory, many harmful algae produce more toxins and reproduce faster in acidified water. In the wild, similar reactions could harm people who consume contaminated shellfish, sick fish, and marine mammals.

FISH

Approximately 20% of the world's population derives at least one-fifth of their animal protein intake from fish. Ocean acidification leads to an increased mortality rate of fish embryos.
